goals.question: What is the overall trend of unemployment across industries?
goals.visualization: Line chart showing the trend of unemployment rate across industries over time
goals.rationale: This visualization helps to identify the industries that have been most affected by unemployment over time.

goals.question: Which industry has the highest unemployment rate?
goals.visualization: Bar chart showing the unemployment rate for each industry
goals.rationale: This visualization helps to identify the industry that has the highest unemployment rate and can be used to focus on the factors that contribute to this trend.

goals.question: What is the relationship between education level and unemployment rate?
goals.visualization: Scatter plot showing the relationship between education level and unemployment rate
goals.rationale: This visualization helps to identify the relationship between education level and unemployment rate and can be used to determine the education level that is most affected by unemployment.

goals.question: What is the distribution of unemployment rate across industries?
goals.visualization: Histogram showing the distribution of unemployment rate across industries
goals.rationale: This visualization helps to identify the industries that have a high or low unemployment rate and can be used to determine the factors that contribute to this trend.

goals.question: What is the average unemployment rate across industries?
goals.visualization: Box plot showing the distribution of unemployment rate across industries
goals.rationale: This visualization helps to identify the average unemployment rate across industries and can be used to compare the industries that have a high or low unemployment rate.

code:
```
import seaborn as sns
import pandas as pd
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

# Load data
data = pd.read_json('unemployment-across-industries.json')

# Convert date field to date type
data['date'] = pd.to_datetime(data['date'], format='%Y-%m-%d', errors='coerce')

# Drop rows with NaT values
data = data[pd.notna(data['date'])]

# Line chart showing the trend of unemployment rate across industries over time
sns.set_style("darkgrid")
sns.set(rc={'figure.figsize':(15,10)})
sns.lineplot(x='date', y='unemployment_rate', hue='industry', data=data)

# Set chart title
plt.title('What is the overall trend of unemployment across industries?', wrap=True)

# Rotate x-axis labels
plt.xticks(rotation=45)

# Show legend
plt.legend(loc='center left', bbox_to_anchor=(1, 0.5))

# Return plot
plt.show()
```

```
import seaborn as sns
import pandas as pd
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

def plot(data: pd.DataFrame):
    data = data.sort_values(by='unemployment_rate', ascending=False)
    sns.set(style="whitegrid")
    ax = sns.barplot(x="industry", y="unemployment_rate", data=data, palette="Blues_d")
    ax.axhline(y=data['unemployment_rate'].max(), color='r', linestyle='--', label='Max unemployment rate: {:.2f}'.format(data['unemployment_rate'].max()))
    ax.set(xlabel='Industry', ylabel='Unemployment rate')
    ax.set_xticklabels(ax.get_xticklabels(), rotation=45, horizontalalignment='right')
    ax.legend()
    return plt

chart = plot(data)
```

```
import seaborn as sns
import pandas as pd
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

def plot(data: pd.DataFrame):
    sns.scatterplot(x='Education Level', y='Unemployment Rate', data=data)
    plt.title('What is the relationship between education level and unemployment rate?', wrap=True)
    return plt

data = pd.read_json('unemployment-across-industries.json')
chart = plot(data)
```

```
import seaborn as sns
import pandas as pd
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

data = pd.read_json('unemployment-across-industries.json')

sns.histplot(data=data, x='unemployment_rate', hue='industry', multiple='stack', kde=True)
plt.title('What is the distribution of unemployment rate across industries?', wrap=True)
plt.xlabel('Unemployment Rate')
plt.ylabel('Frequency')
plt.legend(title='Industry', loc='upper right')

chart = plt
```

```
import seaborn as sns
import pandas as pd
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

def plot(data: pd.DataFrame):
    sns.set(style="whitegrid")
    fig, ax = plt.subplots(figsize=(10, 6))
    sns.boxplot(x="industry", y="unemployment_rate", data=data, ax=ax, palette="Set3")
    ax.axhline(y=data['unemployment_rate'].mean(), color='r', linestyle='--', label=f"Mean: {data['unemployment_rate'].mean():.2f}")
    ax.set_xlabel("Industry")
    ax.set_ylabel("Unemployment Rate")
    ax.set_title("What is the average unemployment rate across industries?")
    ax.legend()
    plt.xticks(rotation=45, ha='right')
    return plt

chart = plot(data)
```
